Troup County held a Ribbon Cutting Ceremony this morning as a way to celebrate the Grand Opening of the Troup County Fire Administration Building & Emergency Operations Center!

Community members came together for the ceremony, which included a program with speakers Ellis Cadenhead, Troup County Commissioner; Patrick Crews, Troup County Commission Chairman; Thomas Moore, GEMA Deputy Director; and John Ekaitis, Troup County Fire Chief.

The newly constructed building, which was completed in the spring, offers several additional amenities to the Troup County Fire Department. It currently accommodates administrative offices and meeting areas, a classroom space for enhanced training capabilities, and the Troup County Operations Center.

Huge thanks to our wonderful community for helping to make this project possible for the Troup County Fire Department. In addition, thanks to the LaGrange - Troup County Chamber of Commerce for kindly supporting this event! #TCFD

The county strongly encourages the public to please stay home if experiencing any symptoms of COVID-19, as well as to please call ahead of time before arrival.

The homeowners were able to escape the house fire unharmed with one of their dogs, but their puppy, Samson, hid in the burning house while responders arrived on scene. Due to their quick response, Firefighters Clayton Bryant and Mark McManus and Lieutenant Richard Kee were able to locate Samson and reunite him with his family.

The homeowners, along with their two dogs, visited the Troup County Fire Department to personally thank Deputy Fire Chief Kevin Norred and the responders involved in the incident for their great service, as well as Sgt. Rodney Williams and Deputy Brian Nappi with the Troup County Sheriff’s Office, as they were the first responders to arrive on scene. Great job to all first responders involved!

The Troup County Fire Department was dispatched to a residential structure fire on Maple Drive in Hogansville at 9:53AM this morning. TCFD Engine 11 arrived within two minutes to the scene, additional fire units to follow.

Upon arrival on the scene, firefighters encountered heavy fire venting from the rear of the structure. Firefighters immediately began an interior attack on the fire. The fire was extinguished within approximately twenty minutes; Firefighters were on the scene for roughly two hours.

The Troup County Fire Department had nineteen firefighters on scene and were assisted by Hogansville Police Department. The cause of the fire is unknown at this time. The fire is currently under investigation by the Troup County Fire Department Fire Marshal’s Office.

There were no reported injuries. #TCFD

As we announced last week, Troup County has suspended recycling services at convenience centers until further notice due to imminent concerns associated with available recycling vendor options and the current outbreak of COVID-19.

At this time, we have terminated all recycling services at convenience centers, excluding the acceptance of corrugated cardboard and metal; however, the LaGrange Recycling Center is still accepting recyclables for those in the community who may be looking for an appropriate place to take recyclables during this time of uncertainty.

The Troup County Sanitation Department is continuing to assess the situation and evaluate additional options. Again, the county was required to make the difficult decision due in large part to the inability to locate a vendor within a reasonable radius that would accept recyclables. Please see our previous post for more details or reach out to staff via email at information@troupco.org for any questions or concerns.

Coronavirus Disease (COVID-19) Update ‼️
*The Troup County Board of Commissioners declared a local state of emergency in Troup County during Tuesday afternoon’s commission meeting, effective immediately.*

The declaration will allow the Board of Commissioners additional flexibility to make speedier decisions regarding functions of the county during the uncertainty of the current circumstances associated with COVID-19. The decision to implement the local state of emergency is a precautionary measure to ensure the protection of the health, safety, and welfare of the citizens of Troup County. At this time, many functions of the county have implemented changes and restrictions due in large part to the current Public Health state of emergency for the State of Georgia as well as the existing Statewide Judicial Emergency. The Troup County Board of Commissioners will continue to assess the rising concerns associated with COVID-19 with support and advice from the Troup County Emergency Management Agency and will provide updates as they arise.

March 17 at 7:47 AM ·

Sheriff James Woodruff

All face-to-face inmate contact has been suspended until further notice. This includes all religious meetings and the DFACS family reunification room. The only exception will be attorney and inmate meetings which will take place through a more secured meeting area.

As this situation continues to change, additional measures may be put in place. Should you have any questions you may contact our Jail Administrator, Capt. Marty Reeves at 706-883-1616.

We appreciate your cooperation in this matter and we also want to take this time to encourage everyone to Remain Calm during this time. Our country is strong and we will get through this as we have during other crisis.

**NOTICE TO VOTERS**

Troup County Absentee Voter info. below! 👇🗳
Georgia allows registered voters to request an absentee ballot by mail without providing a reason as to why he or she is voting absentee! In order to request an absentee ballot, please complete the application located here: https://sos.ga.gov/admin/files/Absentee_Ballot_Application_2018.pdf and return to the Troup County Elections and Registration Office via mail: 100 Ridley Avenue, LaGrange, Georgia 30240, via fax: (706) 883-1692, or via email: elections@troupco.org.

Citizens may request an absentee ballot as early as 180 days before an election. Elderly, disabled, military and military dependents overseas are eligible to receive all ballots for all elections for the remainder of the calendar year after submitting an application. In addition, a physically disabled or illiterate voter may receive application assistance from a close relative. For more information, please visit https://www.troupcountyga.gov/Elections/Absentee. For questions, please call the Elections & Registration Office at (706) 883-1745.

The Troup County Fire Department is pleased to announce the following promotions, effective January 15, 2020:

- Norman Robinson, Fire Lieutenant/EMT to the rank of Battalion Chief
- Richard Kee, Fire Sergeant/EMT to the rank of Lieutenant
- Jeremy “Chase” Freeman, Firefighter/EMT to the rank of Sergeant

Congratulations to these officers on this wonderful achievement! Robinson, Kee, and Freeman are all looking forward to beginning their advanced roles within the Fire Department and are eager to continue their passions for providing exceptional fire service to the citizens of Troup County. They each uniquely possess the knowledge, experience, training, and leadership skills necessary to be strong assets to the community. Fire Chief John Ekaitis extends sincere thanks to all who participated in the promotional process.

City of LaGrange Georgia Government
January 13 at 9:42 AM ·

********UPDATE**********

*ALL STREETS ARE NOW OPEN*

The City of LaGrange wants to alert citizens that several city streets are closed due to flooding.

The National Weather has issued a Flash Flood Warning for parts of Troup County until 2:00 p.m. today, Monday, January 13th.

A Flash Flood Watch has been issued through Wednesday, January 15th until 7:00 a.m.

The following streets are closed to traffic due to flooding:
- Edgewood Avenue
- Glenn Robertson Street
- Swift Street
- Brownwood Avenue
- Park Avenue/Elm Street

Please avoid these areas and use caution when driving. If you see a flooded roadway, turn around. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles.
